medium_description_en: Calculates cardiac output, cardiac index, and stroke volume.

seo.meta_description_en: The Fick Formula calculates cardiac output, cardiac index, and stroke volume.
seo.keywords_en: Fick formula, cardiac output, cardiac index, stroke volume

how_to_use.use_case_en:
• Inpatients with suspected cardiogenic shock and a pulmonary artery catheter in place.

  • For patients undergoing right or left heart catheterization to determine cardiac output (CO), cardiac index (CI), and stroke volume (SV).
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• The two most widely used ways of calculating CO are Fick’s method and the thermodilution technique. Fick’s method is based on the principle that oxygen consumption is equal to the product of the organ’s blood flow (CO) and the difference in the concentration of the substance in the arterial and venous circulation (arterial-venous oxygen difference).

  • Fick’s method is less reliable in patients with pulmonary hypertension, heart failure, or abnormal body habitus.

  • The thermodilution technique is less reliable in patients with tricuspid regurgitation or intracardiac shunting.
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• Assesses cardiac capacity and aids in hemodynamic assessment.

  • Guides management in cardiogenic shock patients, specifically to assess effectiveness of fluid resuscitation, vasopressors, or inotropic support.

next_steps.management_en:
• If CO or CI is low or decreasing, consider increasing fluid administration.

  • If the patient is not fluid responsive, consider adding vasopressors (norEPINEPHrine, DOPamine) via a central line, and use the CO/CI to guide adjustment of vasopressors as per goals of resuscitation (CI >2.5, MAP >60).

about.formula_en:
• CO (Cardiac Output), L/min = VO2/ [(SaO2 - SvO2) x Hb x 13.4)],
    • where VO2 = 125 mL O2/min x BSA,
    • and BSA = [(Height, cm x Weight, kg)/ 3,600 ]1/2
    • In elderly patients (age ≥70 years), use 110 mL O2 x BSA for VO2.
  • CI (Cardiac Index), L/min/m2 = CO/BSA
  • SV (Stroke Volume), mL/beat = CO/HR

Note: SaO2 should be acquired by arterial blood gas measurement. SvO2 should be acquired by mixed venous gas from pulmonary artery catheter. Formula assumes decimal values, not percentages (this calculator automatically converts to decimal values).
about.more_info_en:
Normal values:

  • CO = 4.0-8.0 L/min

  • CI = 2.5-4.0 L/min/m2

  • SV = 60-100 mL/beat

  • MAP ≥60 mmHg

Validation.text: Lafarge CG, Miettinen OS. The estimation of oxygen consumption. Cardiovasc Res. 1970;4(1):23-30.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Ragosta M. Textbook of Clinical Hemodynamics. Elsevier; 2017.

creator_info.about_en: Adolf E. Fick, MD, (d. 1901) was a physiologist at the University of Zurich in Switzerland. Dr. Fick’s research focused primarily on physiology and medical physics.

expert_name.description: Joseph Mizrahi, MD, is an internal medicine resident at Stony Brook University Hospital in New York. Born and raised in Brooklyn, New York, Dr. Mizrahi received his medical degree from the Sackler School of Medicine at Tel Aviv University, and he is also currently a student at the School of Public Health at Stony Brook University. Dr. Mizrahi's areas of interest include gastroenterology and colorectal cancer prevention and screening.
expert_name.name: Joseph Mizrahi, MD

input_schema.tips_en: As measured on mixed venous gas from PA catheter
input_schema.name: venoussat
